awd_titl_txt: Conference Series on Algebra, Geometry, and Combinatorics (ALGECOM)
awd_abstract_narration:
ALGECOM (algebra-geometry-combinatorics) is a series of biannual one day conferences. The main goal is to promote collaboration and regular interaction among midwest students and faculty. Both (non-local) senior and early career mathematicians will be invited as speakers. ALGECOM is now a nearly decade-long tradition in the midwest and has involved over fifty institutions. This grant will fund participant travel to six conferences, the first of which, ALGECOM XVII, will be at Loyola University in Chicago on May 25, 2019. The conference website is at https://sites.google.com/site/algecomday/algecom-xvii.

Each session of ALGECOM consists of four talks and a student poster session. Dissemination of research at the border of algebra, geometry and combinatorics is the basic intellectual merit of the series. There is a wealth of midwest departments with individually small ALGECOM-related research groups. These one day conferences provide the seed for research collaboration among these groups. A major effort has been made to encourage the attendance of graduate students, recent graduates, and untenured faculty. In terms of broader impacts, there are ongoing efforts to recruit women as participants and speakers (in fact ALGECOM 14 had the first all women speaker list). These efforts are enhanced by NSF support, as it allows for invitations to mathematicians from a geographically larger region.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The ALGECOM (Algebra, Geometry, Combinatorics) conference series holds day-long meetings at various universities in the midwest. This grant overlapped with the pandemic period and included Zoom-based conferences at no expense. During the lifetime of the grant, in-person conferences were held at the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign (twice), Loyola University, DePaul University, and Washington University in St. Louis.

Each conference consists of four technical mathematics talks as well as poster sessions for graduate students and postdoctoral scholars. The intellectual merit comes from the exchange of mathematical ideas. The broader impact includes exposure for students and postdocs and their mathematics to each other and to senior faculty. Every effort was made to ensure a diverse group of speakers and attendees.

Testimonials from attendees include:

``I have been a regular participant of ALGECOM since entering graduate school in 2019. The conference has been an excellent venue for graduate students like me to interact with each other and initiate collaboration. For example, I got to know Ayah Almousa during ALGECOM in Oct. 2022. Our conversation later led to a joint project on "Standard Monomials and Grobner bases for positroid varieties". During the same ALGECOM, with Yibo Gao, we made significant progress on our ongoing project regarding minimal equations for Kazhdan-Lusztig varieties.'' (Shiliang Gao, NSF graduate fellow at UIUC; NSF postdoc at Cornell starting Fall 2024)

and

``As a graduate student, ALGECOM was the perfect way to get more exposure to the field and the newest ideas. It also helped me meet othergrad students from other institutions, including one that I struck up a conversation with that resulted in a paper with Tanny Liebman from UCSD!'' (Gidon Orelowitz, Goldman-Sachs)

 


Last Modified: 03/28/2024
Modified by: Alexander T Yong
